div2.p: That if the jury believes from the evidence aforesaid, that the woman Matilda only claimed her freedom by virtue of the letter from Plaintiffs intestate dated in 1827, then no presumption of a deed of manumission cannot be founded on such letter although followed up by her going at large for from the year 1827 to intestates death unless the said intestate was made aware of the fact of her going at large as free during said time

That if the Jury believe that the said Woman Matilda passed as free from 1833 to the bringing of this suit & that the Plaintiffs acquiesced in the same because they were informed by said Francis that he had manumitted her according to the letter of R. B. Gardiner dated in 1827, where which is showed where as the said Francis had not in fact so manumitted her & that the Plaintiffs brought this suit within a few months shortly after discovering that she had not been so manumitted then no presumption can be founded on such acquiescences, as against the Plaintiffs-

That it is competent for the Jury to find from all the circumstances in the case that no deed of manumission was at any time executed by said Francis or said Gardner, & if they find that such deed was executed then the Jury cannot find the issue joined for the Defendant on the Pleas of freedom

That to foresure a deed of manumission of the woman Matilda, the Jury must be satisfied that she acted & passed as free in a manner different from other slaves in Washington City aforesaid then & there held as slaves

Should the Jury be satisfied from the Evidence, that in 1827 Richard B. Gardiner wrote the letter of the 20th Febry. directing Simms to manumit the negro woman Matilda and that neither that said Simms or the said Richard B. Gardner, ever did execute any instrument of writing giving to said Matilda her freedom and that the said Richard B. Gardner did in the year 1832 before any that no such deed of manumission was executed before his death, they may infer therefrom that the power given in said letter, had been was resolved by the said Richard B. Gardner before his death and further that if said the power given in said letter, was not executed before the death of said Richard B. Gardner, that the was resolved by his death in the year 1832-

That from the evidence aforesaid the Jury may find that the defendant purchased the woman Matilda from Edward Sims as & for a slave in the year 1836, & if they further find that during the whole time of her passing as free as claimed by the Defendant she was living with the Defendant as 'his wife' & that it was previous to said purchase by said Defendant of said Sims, then the Jury may infer from the whole evidence aforesaid, that during all the time of her passing as free as alleged the said woman was held & kept by the defendant as the slave of said Sims
from whom he afterwards purchased & that she did not pass as free but was kept by Deft as a slave until the date of his deed of manumission aforesaid-

That if the Jury find that the Defendant executed the deed of manumission stated in the evidence then it is competent for the Jury for the Jury to find from the whole evidence that the Defendant has slavery kept boy George named in the declaration did not pass as free but is now held in servitude by the Defendant as a slave until 21 years of age-

That notwithstanding the Jury may be satisfied from the evidence aforesaid that the letter of the 20th July 1827 was written by Richard B. Gardner in his lifetime, yet it was not sufficient in law, to authorize the said Edward Simms to manumit the said negro woman, Matilda and that the said Matilda and her children who claim freedom in this suit, can claim no legal claim to their freedom under said letter-

That no presumption of a deed of manumission made by the administrator plaintiffs, can be made in as much as no law authorizes administrators to manumit slaves & no there is no presumption that the plaintiffs as administrators have done an illegal or unauthorized act or committed a devastavit

That the Jury are not found from the evidence aforesaid to presume a deed of manumission as claimed by the Defendant by the said Gardner or the plaintiffs or the said Semmis of the woman named Matilda-
(admitted) Defts Counsel the Court adding hereunto on application that it is competent for the Jury to presume such a deed of manumission from the whole evidence aforesaid.

That should the Jury find for br satisfied from the evidence aforesaid, that upon the 23rd day of May, 1836, the Defendant manumitted by legal instrument of writing the said Matilda and her children then born, as his slaves, they may infer therefrom that, the said Defendant did not consider them as going at large as free persons, as to entitle them to their freedom and that he considered them as slaves - upon the said 23rd of May 1836-
